Memorandum
February 8, 2023
To: WIB WIOA Title I Subrecipients
From: Adam Peck, Executive Director
Subject: Guidance on Virtual Service Delivery of WIOA Title I Career and Youth Services

Purpose and Scope
This memo provides guidance on the provision of virtual services for WIOA Title I Eligibility and Youth and Career and Training Services for the Workforce Investment Board of Tulare County (WIB) subrecipients. The guidance is intended to prioritize virtual services that assist individuals who have an urgent and immediate need for enrollment during the COVID-19 pandemic. The policy supersedes the guidance titled Maximizing Distance Technology for WIOA Title I Registration, dated March 31, 2020, and guidance titled Activities and Service Delivery for Remote Services, dated July 23, 2020.

Definition of Remote Services
For the purposes of this policy, remote services involve the exchange of information through a virtual platform, such as Zoom, Google Meet, Teams, or other platforms. Remote services should be meaningful, engaging, and equivalent to receiving in-person services.

Accessibility
Subrecipients should make every effort to ensure that virtual services are accessible to all customers, including those who lack access to technology or reliable internet. When in-person or remote services are not viable, subrecipients should consider meeting customers at an alternative location.

Evaluation of Remote Services
Subrecipients should regularly evaluate the effectiveness of remote services. This could include metrics such as customer satisfaction, enrollment rates, and employment outcomes for those who receive remote services. Subrecipients should use this information to continually improve and refine their remote service offerings.

Customer Focused Service Delivery
All aspects of service delivery should be designed with the needs and interests of customers in mind. Customers may access WIOA Title I program services remotely or in-person based on their preferences or needs.

Remote CalJOBS Eligibility Explorer Application
When conducting remote eligibility, subrecipients should use the CalJOBS Eligibility Explorer Application to assist customers in completing a pre-application and uploading eligibility documents remotely. Intake staff must protect customers' Personal Identifiable Information (PII), and eligibility documents must be uploaded to CalJOBS through the Eligibility Explorer Application, or an in-person appointment should be scheduled to submit eligibility documents. Staff should enter a case note of the customer's request for a remote eligibility appointment.

Coordinated Enrollment
Upon completing the eligibility in-person or remotely, customers shall have access to a career coach the same day for an initial assessment, objective assessment, and My Action Plan.

Remote Electronic Signatures
The WIOA application enables individuals and staff to sign the CalJOBS program applications remotely. Subrecipients should use the CalJOBS Remote Electronic Signature User Guide to assist customers in signing the WIOA application remotely.

Remote Services for Youth and Adult Career Services
Subrecipients may offer remote services via engaging, interactive platforms (Zoom, Google Meet, Teams, etc.) for career services. In addition, electronic applications may be used to obtain signatures for worksite agreements, timesheets, and other related documents. Access to remote Youth and Adult Career Services shall include, but is not limited to:

• Career services, coaching, and guidance
• Work readiness workshops
• Job fairs and industry-specific recruitment
• Business Engagement and outreach
• Signing work-based training documents and other types of documents via electronic applications.

Access to remote workshops shall include, but is not limited to:
• Interviewing skills
• Career Exploration
• Resume development
• How to apply for jobs online and in-person
• Finance and budgeting

develop an outline for a training for staff implementing the policy

Sure, here's an outline for a training for staff implementing the policy:

I. Introduction

* Welcome and introduction of the training facilitator
* Overview of the policy and the importance of adhering to its guidelines
* Explanation of the objectives and outcomes of the training session

II. Policy Overview

* Explanation of the policy's purpose and scope
* Discussion of the definition of remote services and customer-focused service delivery
* Examination of the policy's principles and best practices

III. Remote CalJOBS Eligibility Explorer Application

* Explanation of how to use the Eligibility Explorer Application to assist customers in completing a pre-application and uploading eligibility documents remotely
* Demonstration of how to upload eligibility documents to CalJOBS through the Eligibility Explorer Application
* Review of how to enter case notes for remote eligibility appointments

IV. Coordinated Enrollment

* Explanation of how to provide customers with access to a career coach the same day for an initial assessment, objective assessment, and My Action Plan
* Demonstration of how to coordinate enrollment in-person or remotely

V. Remote Electronic Signatures

* Explanation of how to use the CalJOBS Remote Electronic Signature User Guide to assist customers in signing the WIOA application remotely
* Review of how to obtain electronic signatures for worksite agreements, timesheets, and other related documents

VI. Remote Services for Youth and Adult Career Services

* Explanation of how to provide remote services via engaging, interactive platforms such as Zoom, Google Meet, and Teams
* Discussion of the types of remote services available, including career services, coaching, guidance, work readiness workshops, job fairs, industry-specific recruitment, business engagement, outreach, and signing work-based training documents and other types of documents via electronic applications
* Review of the types of remote workshops available, including interviewing skills, career exploration, resume development, how to apply for jobs online and in-person, finance, and budgeting

VII. Accessibility

* Discussion of how to make virtual services accessible to all customers, including those who lack access to technology or reliable internet
* Explanation of how to meet customers at alternative locations when in-person or remote services are not viable

VIII. Evaluation of Remote Services

* Explanation of how to evaluate the effectiveness of remote services
* Review of the metrics to use, such as customer satisfaction, enrollment rates, and employment outcomes for those who receive remote services
* Discussion of how to use this information to continually improve and refine remote service offerings

IX. Conclusion

* Recap of the key takeaways from the training session
* Opportunity for participants to ask questions or provide feedback
* Final remarks from the training facilitator
Develop a few activities within the meeting for staff to practice implementing the policy.

Sure, here are a few activities that could be used during the training session to help staff practice implementing the policy:

1. Role-Playing Exercise
* Divide participants into pairs, with one person acting as the customer and the other as the career coach or intake staff.
* Provide participants with different scenarios in which a customer may need to access remote services, such as a lack of transportation or living in a remote location.
* Instruct participants to use the policy guidelines to provide the customer with a remote service that is equivalent to receiving in-person services.
* After the role-playing exercise, provide feedback to each pair on what they did well and what could be improved.
2. CalJOBS Eligibility Explorer Application Exercise
* Provide participants with a scenario in which a customer needs to complete a pre-application and upload eligibility documents remotely.
* Instruct participants to use the CalJOBS Eligibility Explorer Application to assist the customer in completing the pre-application and uploading the documents.
* After the exercise, ask participants to share their experiences and provide feedback on the process.
3. Remote Workshop Exercise
* Divide participants into small groups and provide them with a scenario in which a customer needs to access a remote workshop, such as a resume development workshop.
* Instruct participants to use a virtual platform such as Zoom, Google Meet, or Teams to deliver the workshop to the customer.
* After the exercise, ask participants to share their experiences and provide feedback on the process, including how they engaged the customer and made the workshop interactive.
4. Evaluation Exercise
* Divide participants into small groups and provide them with a hypothetical remote service that they can evaluate, such as a virtual job fair.
* Instruct participants to use the policy guidelines to evaluate the effectiveness of the remote service using metrics such as customer satisfaction, enrollment rates, and employment outcomes.
* After the exercise, ask participants to share their findings with the group and discuss how the remote service could be improved based on their evaluation.

These activities can help staff practice implementing the policy in a practical way, while also providing an opportunity for feedback and reflection on the process.
